citation.article-title: Palleronia marisminoris gen. nov., sp. nov., a moderately halophilic, exopolysaccharide-producing bacterium belonging to the 'Alphaproteobacteria', isolated from a saline soil.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Palleronia (Pall.er.o′nia. N.L. sb. f. Palleronia in honour of Professor Norberto Palleroni, a pioneer in the use of molecular identification techniques in prokaryote taxonomy).
Gram-negative, short, non-motile rods, 2–2·5 μm long by 0·75–1 μm wide.
Neither flagella nor endospores are present.
Metabolism is chemoheterotrophic and aerobic, the cells being unable to grow under anaerobic conditions either by fermentation, nitrate or fumarate reduction or photoheterotrophy.
The bacteria cannot produce acids from sugars and have low nutritional and biochemical versatility.
They are strictly halophilic, requiring Na+, Mg2+ and K+ for growth.
The principal cellular fatty acids are 18 : 1ω7c and 19 : 0 cyclo ω8c.
They have ubiquinone with ten isoprene units.
The type species is Palleronia marisminoris.
